9.71.text:
Okay, so today’s episode is Colonizing the
Outer Solar System, and is actually part 2

15.54.text:
of our team up with Fraser Cain of Universe
Today, who looked at the inner solar system.

21.91.text:
If you are regular here you might want jump
over there now and watch that part first,

27.82.text:
if you are coming in from having seen part
1, welcome, it is great having you here, and

32.61.text:
as a heads up I do have a bit of speech impediment
so you should probably turn on the closed

39.17.text:
Without further ado let us get started. First
off, there is no official demarcation between

45.03.text:
the inner and outer solar system but for today
we will be beginning the outer solar system

50.77.text:
at the Asteroid Belt.
The Asteroid Belt is always of interest to

55.22.text:
us for colonization. We have talked about
mining them before if you want the details

59.59.text:
on that but for today I’ll just remind everyone
that they’re are very rich in metals, including

64.80.text:
precious metals like gold and platinum, and
that provides all the motivation we need to

69.56.text:
colonize them. We have a lot of places to
cover so we won’t repeat the details on

74.38.text:
that today.
You cannot terraform asteroids the way you

78.70.text:
could Venus or Mars so that you could walk
around on them like Earth, but in every other

83.23.text:
respect they have a lot going for them as
a candidate. They’ve got plenty of rock

87.98.text:
and metal for construction, they have lots
of the basic organic elements, and they even

92.59.text:
have some water. They also get a decent amount
of sunlight, less than Mars let alone Earth,

98.81.text:
but still enough for use as a power source
and to grow plants.

103.11.text:
But they don’t have much gravity, which
- pardon the pun - has its ups and downs.

108.60.text:
There just isn’t much mass in the Belt.
The entire thing has only a small fraction

113.09.text:
of the mass of our moon, and over half of
that is in the four biggest asteroids, essentially

118.43.text:
dwarf planets in their own right. The remainder
is scattered over millions of asteroids. Even

124.64.text:
the biggest, Ceres, is only about 1% of 1%
of Earth’s mass, has a surface gravity of

131.27.text:
3% Earth-normal, and an escape velocity low
enough most model rockets could get into orbit.

137.86.text:
And again, it is the biggest, most you could
get away from by jumping hard and if you dropped

143.15.text:
an object on one it might take a few minutes
to land.

146.80.text:
You can still terraform one though, by definition
too. The gentleman who coined the term, science

152.86.text:
fiction author Jack Williamson, who also coined
the term genetic engineering, used it for

158.33.text:
a smaller asteroid just a few kilometers across,
so any definition of terraforming has to include

164.04.text:
tiny asteroids as well.
Of course in that story it’s like a small

167.85.text:
planet because they had artificial gravity,
we don’t, if we want to fake gravity without

172.91.text:
having mass we need to spin stuff around.
So if we want to terraform an asteroid we

177.98.text:
need to hollow it out and fill it with air
and spin it around.

181.67.text:
Of course you do not actually hollow out the
asteroid and spin it, asteroids are loose

186.05.text:
balls of gravel and most would fly apart given
any noticeable spin. Instead you would hollow

191.92.text:
it out and set a cylinder spinning inside
it. Sort of like how a good thermos has an

196.73.text:
outside container and inside one with a layer
of vacuum in between, we would spin the inner

202.73.text:
cylinder.
You wouldn’t have to work hard to hollow

204.82.text:
out an asteroid either, most aren’t big
enough to have sufficient gravity and pressure

209.19.text:
to crush an empty beer can even at their center.
So you can pull matter out from them very

213.89.text:
easily and shore up the sides with very thin
metal walls or even ice. Or just have your

218.61.text:
cylinder set inside a second non-spinning
outer skin or superstructure, like your washer

223.46.text:
or dryer has.
You can then conduct your mining from the

227.42.text:
inside, shielded from space. You could even
pressurize that hollowed out area if your

231.92.text:
spinning living area was inside its own superstructure.
No gravity, but warmth and air, and you could

238.22.text:
get away with just a little spin without tearing
it apart, maybe enough for plants to grow

242.53.text:
to normally. Zero gravity experiments with
plants have shown them to grow just fine without

248.12.text:
gravity but it probably helps to have a little
to make sure water falls down and trees grow

253.21.text:
up. You could probably get some monstrously
tall trees in low-gravity too.

259.21.text:
Moving on to Jupiter, it should be noted that
you can potentially colonize even the gas

263.29.text:
giants themselves, even though our focus today
is mostly on their moons. That requires a

269.57.text:
lot more effort and technology then the sorts
of colonies we are discussing today. Fraser

274.78.text:
and I decided to keep things near-future and
fairly low tech, though he actually did an

279.36.text:
article on colonizing Jupiter itself last
year that was my main source material back

284.55.text:
before we got to talking and decided to do
a video together, so I will include that in

289.11.text:
the episode description if you are interested.
Hydrogen is plentiful on Jupiter itself and

294.36.text:
floating refineries or ships that fly down
to scoop it up might be quite useful, but

299.25.text:
again today we are more interested in its
moons. The biggest problem with colonizing

304.60.text:
the moons of Jupiter is all the radiation
the planet gives off.

309.16.text:
Gas giants tend to have immense magnetospheres,
which is normally a great thing for shielding

314.11.text:
you from radiation, unfortunately it also
traps charged particles. Earth has the van

320.17.text:
Allen Belt as a result, which is not a healthy
place to hang out. Jupiter’s equivalent

325.78.text:
of this is far bigger and deadlier and includes
many of its moons.

330.62.text:
Which means that even though three of Jupiter’s
moons are bigger than our moon, and the biggest,

336.44.text:
Ganymede, is bigger than both Pluto and Mercury,
our interest falls to the fourth biggest one,

341.88.text:
Europa, that has a nice thick layer of protective
ice we can easily use for radiation shielding.

347.65.text:
Which isn’t to say the others don’t interest
us too, but they are much more like colonizing

351.98.text:
our own moon, just plus tons of radiation,
or in Io’s case, non-stop volcanoes and

359.38.text:
Europa is best known as a place where the
surface is covered with ice but beneath it

363.94.text:
is thought to be a vast subsurface ocean.
It is the sixth largest moon in the solar

368.74.text:
system, coming right behind our own at number
five and is one of the original four moons

373.83.text:
Galileo discovered back in 1610, almost two
centuries before we even discovered Uranus,

379.94.text:
so it has always been a source of interest.
However as we have discovered more planets

384.36.text:
and moons we have come to believe quite a
few of them might also have subsurface oceans

389.31.text:
too.
Now what is neat about them is that water,

392.91.text:
liquid water, always leaves the door open
to the possibility of life already existing

398.34.text:
there. We still know so little about how life
originally evolved and what conditions permit

404.04.text:
that to occur that we cannot rule out places
like Europa already having their own plants

409.02.text:
and animals swimming around under that ice.
They probably do not and obviously we wouldn’t

414.77.text:
want to colonize them, beyond research bases,
if they did, but if they do not they become

420.45.text:
excellent places to colonize. You could have
submarine cities in such places floating around

425.76.text:
in the sea or those buried in the surface
ice layer, well shielded from radiation and

430.67.text:
debris. The water also geysers up to the surface
in some places so you can start off near those,

436.62.text:
you don’t have to drill down through kilometers
of ice on day one.

440.36.text:
Water, and hydrogen, are also quite uncommon
in the inner solar system so having access

445.20.text:
to a place like Europa where the escape velocity
is only about a fifth of our own is quite

450.00.text:
handy for export. Now as we move on to talk
about moons a lot it is important to note

455.49.text:
that when I say something has a fifth of the
escape velocity of Earth that doesn’t mean

460.14.text:
it is fives time easier to get off of it.
Energy rises with the square of velocity so

465.71.text:
if you need to go five times faster you need
to spend 5-squared or 25 times more energy,

472.35.text:
and even more if that place has tons of air
creating friction and drag, atmospheres are

477.74.text:
hard to claw your way up through though they
make landing easier too. But even ignoring

482.71.text:
air friction you can move 25 liters of water
off of Europa for every liter you could export

488.24.text:
from Earth and even it has a very high in
gravity compared to most moons and comets.

494.07.text:
Plus we probably don’t want to export lots
of water, or anything else, off of Earth anyway.

499.94.text:
Jupiter also has the Trojan Asteroids, the
Asteroid Belt is not the only place you find

506.19.text:
asteroids, Jupiter’s Trojan Asteroids are
nearly as numerous, and every planet, including

511.55.text:
Earth, has an equivalent to Jupiter’s Trojan
Asteroids at its own Lagrange Points with

516.38.text:
the Sun. Though just as Jupiter dwarfs all
the other planets so to does its collection

521.84.text:
of Lagrangian objects. They can be quite big
too, the largest 624 Hektor, is 400 km across,

530.27.text:
and has a size and shape similar to Pennsylvania.
And as these asteroids are at stable Lagrange

535.79.text:
Points, they orbit with Jupiter but always
ahead and behind it, making transit to and

541.08.text:
from Jupiter much easier and making them good
waypoints.

545.91.text:
Before we go out any further in the solar
system we should probably address how you

549.65.text:
get the energy to stay alive. Mars is already
quite cold compared to Earth, and the Asteroids

556.13.text:
and Jupiter even more so, but with thick insulation
and some mirrors to bounce light in you can

561.91.text:
do fairly decently. Indeed, sunlight out by
Jupiter is already down to just 4% of what

567.66.text:
Earth gets, meaning at Jovian distances it
is about 50 W/m²

573.38.text:
That might not sound like much but it is actually
almost a third of what average illumination

577.87.text:
is on Earth, when you factor in atmospheric
reflection, cloudy days, nighttime, and higher,

583.88.text:
colder latitudes. It is also a good deal brighter
than the inside of most well-lit buildings,

589.90.text:
and is enough for decently robust photosynthesis
to grow food. Especially with supplemental

595.14.text:
light from mirrors or LED growth lamps.
But once you get out to Saturn and further

600.71.text:
that becomes increasingly impractical and
a serious issue, because while food growth

605.08.text:
does not show up on your electric bill it
is what we use virtually all our energy for.

611.46.text:
Closer in to the sun we can use solar panels
for power and we do not need any power to

615.95.text:
grow food. As we get further out we cannot
use solar and we need to heat our cold habitats

622.03.text:
and supply lighting for food, so we need a
lot more power even as our main source dries

627.45.text:
up.
So what are our options? Well the first is

631.97.text:
simple, build bigger mirrors. A mirror can
be quite large and paper thin after all. Alternatively

638.07.text:
we can build those mirrors far away, closer
to the sun, and either focus them on the place

643.21.text:
we want illuminated or send an energy beam,
microwaves perhaps or lasers, out to the destination

649.65.text:
to supply energy.
We also have the option of using fission,

653.65.text:
if we can find enough Uranium or Thorium.
There is not a lot of either in the solar

658.09.text:
system, in the area of about one part per
billion, but that does amount to hundreds

663.15.text:
of trillions of tons, and it should only take
a few thousand tons a year to supply Earth’s

668.72.text:
entire electric grid. So we would be looking
at millions of years’ worth of energy supply.

674.40.text:
Of course fusion is even better, particularly
since hydrogen becomes much more abundant

679.24.text:
as you get further from the Sun. We do not
have fusion yet, but it is a technology we

685.17.text:
can plan around probably having inside our
lifetimes, and while uranium and thorium might

690.39.text:
be counted in parts per billion, hydrogen
is more plentiful than every other element

694.78.text:
combined, especially once you get far from
the Sun and Inner Solar System.

699.89.text:
So it is much better power source, an effectively
unlimited one except on time scales of billions

705.38.text:
and trillion of years. Still, if we do not
have it, we have other options. Bigger mirrors,

712.48.text:
beaming energy outwards from closer to the
Sun, and classic fission of Uranium and Thorium.

718.73.text:
Access to fusion is not absolutely necessary
but if you have it you can unlock the outer

724.33.text:
solar system because you have your energy
supply, a cheap and abundant fuel supply,

729.62.text:
and much faster and cheaper spaceships.
Of course hydrogen, plain old vanilla hydrogen

735.64.text:
with one proton, like the sun uses for fusion,
is harder to fuse than deuterium and may be

741.77.text:
a lot longer developing, we also have fusion
using Helium-3 which has some advantages over

747.29.text:
hydrogen, so that is worth keeping in mind
as well as we proceed outward.

751.82.text:
Okay, let’s move on to Saturn, and again
our focus is on its moons more than the planet

757.63.text:
itself. The biggest of those and the most
interesting for colonization is Titan.

763.50.text:
Titan is aptly named, this titanic moon contains
more mass than all of Saturn’s sixty or

768.76.text:
so other moons combined and by an entire order
of magnitude at that. It is massive enough

774.32.text:
to hold an atmosphere, and one where the surface
pressure is 45% higher than here on Earth.

780.16.text:
Even though Titan is much smaller than Earth,
its atmosphere is about 20% more massive than

784.95.text:
our own. It’s almost all nitrogen too, even
more than our own atmosphere, so while you

790.68.text:
would need a breather mask to supply oxygen
and it is also super-cold, so you’d need

795.15.text:
a thick insulated suit, it doesn’t have
to be a pressure suit like it would on Mars

799.62.text:
or almost anyplace else.
There’s no oxygen in the atmosphere, what

804.63.text:
little isn’t nitrogen is mostly methane
and hydrogen, but there is plenty of oxygen

809.38.text:
in the ice on Titan which is quite abundant.
So it has everything we need for life except

814.77.text:
energy and gravity. At 14% of earth normal
it is probably too low for people to comfortably

820.47.text:
and safely adapt to, but we’ve already discussed
ways of dealing with that. It is low enough

825.95.text:
that you could probably flap your arms and
fly, if you had wings attached.

830.61.text:
It needs some source of energy though, and
we just discussed that. Obviously if you’ve

835.25.text:
got fusion you have all the hydrogen you need,
but Titan is one of those places we would

840.37.text:
probably want to colonize early on if we could,
it has nitrogen which is something you need

845.71.text:
a lot of to terraform other places, and is
also rich in a lot of the others things we

850.12.text:
want. So we often think of it as a low-tech
colony since it is one we would want early

855.24.text:
on.
In any scenario like that it is very easy

858.30.text:
to imagine a lot of local transit between
Titan and its smaller neighboring moons, which

863.74.text:
are more rocky and might be easier to dig
fissile materials like Uranium and Thorium

868.36.text:
out of. You might have a dozen or so small
outposts on neighboring moons mining fissile

873.50.text:
materials and other metals and a big central
hub on Titan they delivered that to which

878.67.text:
also exported Nitrogen to other colonies in
the solar system.

882.99.text:
Moving back and forth between moons is pretty
easy, especially since things landing on Titan

888.02.text:
can aerobrake quite easily, whereas Titan
itself has a pretty strong gravity well and

892.99.text:
thick atmosphere to climb out of but is a
good candidate for a space elevator, since

897.73.text:
it requires nothing more sophisticated than
a Lunar Elevator on our own moon and has an

902.30.text:
abundant supply of the materials needed to
make Zylon for instance, a material strong

907.36.text:
enough to make an elevator there and which
we can mass manufacture right now.

912.72.text:
Titan might be the largest and most useful
of Saturn’s moons, but again it isn’t

916.95.text:
the only one and not all of the other are
just rocks for mining. At last count it has

922.01.text:
over sixty and many of them quite large. One
of those, Enceladus, Saturn’s sixth largest

928.60.text:
moon, is a lot like Jupiter’s Moon Europa,
in that we believe it has a large and thick

933.43.text:
subsurface ocean. So just like Europa it is
an interesting candidate for Colonization.

939.11.text:
So Titan might be the hub for Saturn but it
wouldn’t be the only significant place to

945.31.text:
While Saturn is best known for its amazing
rings, they tend to be overlooked in colonization.

950.93.text:
Now those rings are almost all ice and in
total mass about a quarter as much as Enceladus,

956.48.text:
which again is Saturn’s Sixth largest moon,
which is itself not even a thousandth of the

961.57.text:
Mass of Titan.
In spite of that the rings are not a bad place

964.99.text:
to set up shop. Being mostly water, they are
abundant in hydrogen for fusion fuel and have

971.13.text:
little mass individually, which makes them
as easy to approach or leave as an asteroid.

976.95.text:
Just big icebergs in space really, and there
are many moonlets in the rings that can be

981.87.text:
as large as half a kilometer across. So you
can burrow down inside one for protection

987.34.text:
from radiation and impacts and possibly mine
smaller ones for their ice to be brought to

992.19.text:
places where water is not abundant.
In total those rings, which are all frozen

997.46.text:
water, only mass about 2% of Earth’s oceans,
and about as much as the entire Antarctic

1003.92.text:
sheet. So it is a lot of fresh water that
is very easy to access and move elsewhere,

1009.71.text:
and ice mines in the rings of Saturn might
be quite useful and make good homes too. Living

1015.98.text:
inside an iceball might not sound appealing
but it is better than it sounds like and we

1020.96.text:
will discuss that more when we reach the Kupier
Belt.

1024.30.text:
But first we still have two more planets to
look at, Uranus and Neptune.

1029.04.text:
Uranus, and Neptune, are sometimes known as
Ice Giants instead of Gas Giants because they

1035.41.text:
have a lot more water. They also have more
ammonia and methane and all three get called

1040.57.text:
ices in this context because they make up
most of the solid matter when you get this

1045.00.text:
far out in the solar system.
While Jupiter is over a thousand times the

1049.43.text:
mass of Earth, Uranus weighs in at about 15
times the Earth and has only about double

1054.67.text:
the escape velocity of Earth itself, the least
of any of the gas giants, and its strange

1061.04.text:
rotation, and its strange tilt contributes
to it having much less wind than other giants.

1067.32.text:
Additionally the gravity is just a little
less than Earth’s in the atmosphere so we

1071.87.text:
have the option for floating habitats again,
though it would be a lot more like a submarine

1076.66.text:
than a hot air balloon.
Like Venus, Uranus has very long days, at

1081.89.text:
least in terms of places receiving continual
sunlight, the poles get 42 years of perpetual

1088.16.text:
sunlight then 42 years of darkness. Sunlight
being a relative term, the light is quite

1095.20.text:
minimal especially inside the atmosphere.
The low wind in many places makes it a good

1100.00.text:
spot for gas extraction, such as Helium-3,
and it's a good planet to try to scoop gas

1105.22.text:
from or even have permanent installations.
Now Uranus has a large collection of moons

1111.01.text:
as well, useful and colonizable like the other
moons we have looked at, but otherwise unremarkable

1117.16.text:
beyond being named for characters from Shakespeare,
rather than the more common mythological names.

1123.08.text:
None have atmospheres though there is a possibility
Oberon or Titania might have subsurface oceans.

1130.88.text:
Neptune makes for a brief entry, it is very
similar to Uranus except it has the characteristically

1136.17.text:
high winds of gas giants that Uranus’s skewed
poles mitigate, meaning it has no advantages

1141.81.text:
over Uranus and the disadvantages of high
wind speeds everywhere and being even further

1147.59.text:
from the Sun. It also has moons and one of
them, Triton, is thought to have subsurface

1153.56.text:
oceans as well. Triton also presumably has
a good amount of nitrogen inside it since

1158.49.text:
it often erupts geysers of nitrogen from its
surface.

1162.11.text:
Triton is one of the largest moons in the
solar system, coming in seventh just after

1166.65.text:
our Moon, number 5, and Europa at number 6.
Meaning that were it not a moon it would probably

1172.88.text:
qualify as a Dwarf Planet and it is often
thought Pluto might be an escaped moon of

1177.32.text:
Neptune. So Triton might be one that didn’t
escape, or didn’t avoid getting captured.

1183.37.text:
We’ve talked before about colonizing icy
dwarf planets like Pluto, and there are several

1188.08.text:
essentially identical objects to Pluto in
the Solar System, so we won’t do another

1192.70.text:
entry just for Pluto. In fact there are an
awful lot of bodies in this general size range

1197.56.text:
and composition wandering about in the outer
regions of our solar system as we get out

1205.16.text:
The Kupier Belt is one of those things that
has a claim on the somewhat arbitrary and

1209.08.text:
hazy boundary marking the edge of the Solar
System. It extends from out past Neptune to

1214.01.text:
beyond Pluto and contains a good deal more
mass than the asteroid Belt. It is where a

1219.45.text:
lot of our comets come from and while there
is plenty of rocks out there they tend to

1223.31.text:
be covered in ice. In other words it is like
our asteroid belt only there’s more of it

1228.93.text:
and the one thing the belt is not very abundant
in, water and hydrogen in general, is quite

1233.50.text:
abundant out there. So if you have a power
source like fusion they can be easily terraformed

1239.15.text:
and are just as attractive as a source of
minerals as the various asteroids and moons

1243.49.text:
closer in.
We mentioned the idea of living inside hollowed

1247.25.text:
out asteroids earlier and you can use the
same trick for comets. Indeed you could shape

1252.32.text:
them to be much bigger if you like, since
they would be hollow and ice isn’t hard

1256.66.text:
to move and shape especially in zero gravity.
Same trick as before, you place a spinning

1261.74.text:
cylinder inside it. Not all the object is
entirely ice and indeed your average comet

1268.28.text:
is more a frozen ball of mud then ice. And
most would have rocky cores. We think a lot

1273.89.text:
of near Earth Asteroids are just leftover
comets. So they are probably pretty good homes

1278.90.text:
if you have fusion, lots of fuel and raw materials
for both life and construction.

1284.47.text:
This is probably your cheapest interstellar
spacecraft too, in terms of effort anyway.

1290.13.text:
People often talk about re-directing comets
to Mars to bring it air and water, but you

1294.56.text:
can just as easily re-direct it out of the
solar system entirely. Comets tend to have

1299.20.text:
highly eccentric orbits, so if you capture
one when it is near the Sun you can accelerate

1304.03.text:
it then, actually benefiting from the Oberth
Effect, and drive it out of the solar system

1308.93.text:
into deep space. If you have a fusion power
source to live inside one then you also have

1314.23.text:
an interstellar spaceship drive, so you just
carve yourself a small colony inside the comet

1319.42.text:
and head out into deep space.
You’ve got supplies that will last you many

1323.54.text:
centuries at least, even if it were home to
tens of thousand of people, and while we think

1328.29.text:
of smaller asteroids and comets as tiny, that’s
just in comparison to planets. These things

1334.10.text:
tend to be the size of mountain so there is
plenty of living space and a kilometer of

1338.67.text:
dirty ice between you and space makes a great
shield against even the kinds of radiation

1343.80.text:
and collisions you can experience at relativistic
speeds.

1348.82.text:
Now the Oort Cloud is much like the Kupier
Belt but begins even further out and extends

1353.88.text:
out probably an entire light year or more.
We don’t have a firm idea of its exact dimensions

1359.92.text:
or mass, but the current notion is that it
has at least several Earth’s worth of mass,

1365.67.text:
mostly in various icy bodies. These will be
quite numerous, estimates usually assumes

1370.52.text:
at least trillion icy bodies a kilometer across
or bigger, and even more smaller ones. However

1376.79.text:
the volume of space is so large that those
kilometer wide bodies might each be around

1382.12.text:
a billion kilometers distant from neighbors,
